original_title: Sri Lanka amends new fuel supplier deal to smoothen pressure on exchange rate – minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka has amended the agreement with three new fuel suppliers and allowed them to convert rupees into dollars from the start in order to prevent any pressure on the rupee, Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera said.
Sri Lanka has awarded retail fuel licenses to three foreign firms, namely, China’s Sinopec, United Petroleum Australia and US-based RM Parks, which is in collaboration with Shell.
According to the original agreement, the suppliers were asked to keep their rupee earnings for nine months without converting into US dollars.

“But this clause has been changed on the advice of the central bank. The central bank said there could be possible pressure on the exchange rate when they try to convert huge amounts of rupee into dollars at once after nine months,” Wijesekera told a media briefing on Tuesday (04).
“This is amended in such a way that they can convert rupees as and when they want.”
The Minister also said there was no change on retaining fuel suppliers’ dollar investments in Sri Lanka for at least 12 months. (Colombo/July 05/2023)
